Fig. 1 (a) XRD patterns, (b) Co 2p3/2 XPS spectra, and (c) O 1 s XPS spectra of calcined CAP and CAPM catalysts. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts; (b) XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts; (c, d) TEM images and (e) EDX elemental mapping of Al, Co, Mo, and Pt for the CAPM-10 catalyst reduced at 300 °C; Element-specific EDX maps are shown for (f) Al, (g) Co, (h) Mo, and (i) Pt. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) H2-TPD and (b) CO2-TPD profiles of the reduced catalysts. The CO2-TPD profile was plotted as TCD signal vs. time, with temperature shown on the secondary y-axis. This format captures both the heating and isothermal (800 °C) desorption stages for accurate interpretation. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) Productivity and (b) selectivity of various products from CO2 hydrogenation over CAP and CAPM catalysts. Reaction conditions: 180 °C, 4 MPa, H2/CO2 = 1, 1 h, in water. The error bar was calculated based on three independent measurements. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) XRD patterns, (b) H2-TPR, (c) H2-TPD, and (d) CO2-TPD profiles of CAPM catalysts synthesized at different precipitation pH; (e) H2-TPD and (f) CO2-TPD profiles of CAPM-8.5 catalyst reduced at various temperatures. The CO2-TPD profile was plotted as TCD signal vs. time, with temperature shown on the secondary y-axis. This format captures both the heating and isothermal (800 °C) desorption stages for accurate interpretation. The catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 offers a sustainable route to convert a major greenhouse gas into value-added fuels and chemicals. Among various catalysts, cobalt (Co)-based materials have attracted attention due to their structural versatility and high activity; however, their strong hydrogenation capacity typically favors methane formation over higher-value products such as alcohols. In this study, we report a Mo-promoted CoAlPt catalyst synthesized via ion exchange to modulate product selectivity in CO2 hydrogenation. The Mo-promoted CoAlPt catalyst achieved a notable alcohol productivity of 521 μmol gcat −1 h−1 with an alcohol selectivity of 21.5 % (CO-free), of which higher alcohols accounted for 64.0 %. Simultaneously, methane formation was significantly suppressed (from 14,265 to 1898 μmol gcat −1 h−1), while CO productivity increased by nearly three folds. Mechanistic investigations attribute this performance enhancement to Mo-induced modulation of Co active sites, which promotes the formation of medium and strongly adsorbed *CO2 species. This shifts the reaction pathway toward bidentate *HCOO intermediate conversion, ultimately reducing CH4 formation and favoring alcohol production. These findings highlight the potential of Mo as a promoter in Co-based catalysts for tuning selectivity in CO2 hydrogenation. Graphical Abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Cobalt Molybdenum Surface adsorption Methanol Higher alcohol Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction CO2, while a major greenhouse gas, also represents a valuable carbon feedstock for chemical synthesis. Capture and utilization of CO2 not only curbs emissions but also produces value-added fuels and chemicals, delivering both environmental and economic benefits [1,2]. CO2 hydrogenation—using green H2 generated by renewable-powered water electrolysis—reintegrates captured CO2 into the carbon cycle, promoting true carbon circularity [3]. To date, a range of catalysts (Ni-, Co-, In-, Cu-, Rh- and Fe-based) have been explored for CO2 hydrogenation, yielding products such as methane, long-chain hydrocarbons, CO, methanol and higher alcohols [4,5]. Co-based materials—ranging from metallic cobalt (Co0) and cobalt oxide (CoO) to cobalt carbide (Co2C) and partially oxidized species (Coδ+), as well as their composites—provide a spectrum of active species and sites for CO2 hydrogenation, driving the formation of methane, long-chain hydrocarbons, methanol and higher alcohols [6,7]. Their structural versatility and tunable catalytic performance in CO2 hydrogenation have garnered intensive research interest. Although Co-based catalysts demonstrate versatility in CO2 hydrogenation, they overwhelmingly favor methane formation, making it difficult to boost productivity and selectivity for higher-value products such as methanol and longer-chain alcohols. For example, our group has engineered a series of CoAl and CoAlPt catalysts: despite achieving high overall CO2 conversion rates through tailored catalyst structures, methane remains the dominant product (46.6 mmol gcat −1 h−1), whereas methanol (509 μmol gcat −1 h−1) and higher alcohols (221 μmol gcat −1 h−1) are formed at much lower rates [8–10]. This behavior is primarily attributed to the strong hydrogenation activity of metallic Co0 and Pt0 [11]. Tailoring catalysts to selectively produce value-added products, such as methanol and higher alcohols, is of critical importance. Specifically, higher alcohols, such as ethanol and propanol, have higher energy densities, lower vapor pressures, and reduced affinity for water compared to methanol, making them more suitable as fuel additives or blending components [12,13]. In addition, higher alcohols typically command higher market prices than methanol, making their production more economically attractive (source: https://www.echemi.com/). The adsorption strength of key intermediates on catalyst surfaces is a critical factor influencing both catalytic activity and selectivity. Alkali metal promoters (Na, K, and Li) enhance the formation of *CO intermediates and facilitate *CO-*CHx coupling, thereby favoring higher alcohol synthesis through CO2 hydrogenation over Co based catalysts [14]. Besides, owing to its unique d‐orbital electronic properties, Mo has been widely employed to finely tune the adsorption behavior of intermediates and enhance CO2 hydrogenation performance [15,16]. Studies have shown that Mo species can modulate electronic effects to weaken the adsorption of *CO and *H on metal surfaces, thereby suppressing methane formation over Pd/anatase-TiO2 catalysts [17]. Besides, Mo can also promote C–O bond retention and C–C coupling, ultimately improving the selectivity toward CO and higher alcohols in CO2 hydrogenation [18,19]. While CoAlPt catalysts exhibit high activity for CO2 hydrogenation, their primary product is methane. Modifying the selectivity toward alcohols by incorporating Mo and elucidating its mechanistic role could offer valuable insights for the rational design of highly active and selective Co-based catalysts. In this study, Mo was introduced into CoAlPt catalysts via ion exchange, resulting in a material denoted as CAPM. The CAPM catalyst achieved an alcohol productivity of 521 μmol gcat −1 h−1 with an alcohol selectivity of 21.5 % (CO-free), of which higher alcohols accounted for 64.0 %. Mo promotion led to a substantial decrease in methane productivity, from 14265 μmol gcat −1 h−1 to 1898 μmol gcat −1 h−1, accompanied by a significant increase in CO productivity from 590 μmol gcat −1 h−1 to 2319 μmol gcat −1 h−1. This enhanced performance is attributed to the Mo-induced modulation of Co active sites, which increases the proportion of medium and strongly adsorbed *CO2 species. This alters the hydrogenation pathway by reducing excessive hydrogenation activity and promoting the formation of bidentate *HCOO, thereby steering the CO2 hydrogenation reaction toward higher selectivity for CO and alcohol. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts The CoAlPt catalysts were synthesized via a modified co-precipitation method based on our previous work [20]. Briefly, two precursor solutions were prepared: Solution A contained 0.012 M Al(NO3)3·9 H2O, 0.108 M Co(NO3)2·6 H2O, and 0.0036 M H2PtCl6; Solution B consisted of 0.4 M NaOH. Under continuous stirring and ice-bath conditions, Solution A was added dropwise to Solution B using a peristaltic pump, maintaining the pH within the range of 8.5–10.5. The resulting slurry was filtered, and the precipitate was washed thoroughly with deionized water to remove residual ions. The solid was then dried at 80 °C for 6 h, ground into a fine powder, and subsequently mixed with 0.515 g Na2MoO4 in 25 mL ultrapure water. The mixture was stirred for 24 h to promote ion exchange between the intercalated OH− ions in the precipitated Co/Al hydroxide precursor and MoO4 2−, resulting in the formation of MoO4 2−-intercalated Co and Al hydroxides [21]. The resulting solid was then separated by filtration and thoroughly washed with deionized water. The final solid was dried at 80 °C for 12 h, calcined at 400 °C for 2 h, and reduced under H2 at 200–400 °C for 3 h before catalytic test. The catalysts begin to reduce at 200 °C and reaches full reduction by 400 °C. At an intermediate reduction temperature of 300 °C, cobalt is only partially reduced, yielding both metallic Co0 and oxidic Co2+ sites. This dual-site architecture fosters a synergistic interaction that significantly improves CO2 conversion. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was conducted using a Varian 720ES instrument to quantify the concentrations of Co, Al, Pt, and Mo in the catalysts. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed to examine the crystal structures using a Rigaku SmartLab diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.5406 Å, 40 kV, 40 mA). Diffraction patterns were collected over a 2θ range of 5–90° at a scanning rate of 10° min−1, and crystallite sizes were estimated using the Scherrer equation [22]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on a Kratos Axis Supra spectrometer to analyze the surface chemical states. All binding energies were calibrated with respect to the C 1 s peak of adventitious carbon at 284.8 eV. Structural characterization was performed using a FEI Talos F200S field-emission transmission electron microscope (TEM) operated at 200 kV, coupled with an integrated windowless Super FEI-X energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) system (30 mm2 × 2, energy resolution < 136 eV). H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD), and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) experiments were conducted using a VDSorb-9Xi chemisorption analyzer. For H2-TPR, approximately 50 mg of catalyst was loaded into a U-shaped quartz reactor and pretreated under an Ar flow (30 mL min−1) at 150 °C for 1 h. After cooling to 70 °C, the gas flow was switched to 10 % H2/Ar (30 mL min−1), and the temperature was ramped from 50 to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1, followed by a 10-minute isothermal hold at 800 °C. The effluent gas was continuously monitored using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For H2-TPD, the catalysts were first reduced in a 10 % H2/Ar flow at 200–400 °C for 3 h. After reduction, the samples were cooled to 100 °C under Ar and stabilized for 30 min. H2 adsorption was then performed by exposing the samples to 10 % H2/Ar at 100 °C for 1 h, followed by an Ar purge (30 mL min−1) for 1 h to remove physisorbed species. Desorption was carried out by heating the samples from 100 to 700 °C at 10 °C min−1 with a 50-minute isothermal plateau at 800 °C, during which the TCD signal was recorded. For CO2-TPD, the catalysts pre-reduced at 200–400 °C under H2 for 3 h were cooled to 50 °C in Ar and stabilized for 1 h. CO2 adsorption was conducted by flowing 5 % CO2/He (30 mL min−1) over the sample at 50 °C for 1 h, followed by flushing with He (30 mL min−1) for 1 h to remove weakly bound CO2. Desorption was performed by heating from 50 to 800 °C at 10 °C min−1 with a 50-minute isothermal hold at 800 °C, and TCD signals were continuously monitored. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation CO2 hydrogenation reactions were carried out in a 50 mL PTFE-lined stainless-steel autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirrer. Typically, 15 mL of deionized water and 50 mg of the pre-reduced catalyst were introduced into the reactor. The system was purged five times with CO2 (1 MPa) to remove residual air. Subsequently, CO2 and H2 were introduced to a total pressure of 4 MPa (2 MPa each). The reaction was conducted at 180 °C under continuous stirring at 350 rpm for 1 h. The partial pressure, reaction temperature, and reaction time were also varied to investigate the effects of reaction conditions. Upon completion, the reactor was cooled to approximately 10 °C using an ice-water bath. The gaseous products were collected and analyzed offline using an Agilent 8890 gas chromatograph equipped with a TCD detector, HayeSep Q, and MolSieve 5 A columns. Methane was quantified using external calibration standards, and its amount was calculated based on the ideal gas law. Liquid-phase products were analyzed using an Agilent 8860 gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector and an HP-Innowax column. Tetrahydrofuran was used as the internal standard. Productivity, turnover frequency, and selectivity for methanol, ethanol, propanol, butanol, methane, and CO were calculated according to the following equations: (1) P i = n i t × m cat (2) TOF = P tot n as (3) n as = n H 2 × 2 (4) S i = P i P tot × 100 % where: P i (μmol gcat −1 h−1) is the productivity of product i (methanol, ethanol, propanol, butanol, methane, or CO), n i (μmol, carbon-based) is the molar amount of product i, t (h) is the reaction time, m cat (g) is the catalyst mass, TOF (h−1) is the turnover frequency of CO2 conversion, n as (μmol gcat −1) is the number of active sites determined by H2-TPD, assuming dissociative H2 adsorption, S i (%) is the selectivity toward product i, P tot (μmol gcat −1 h−1) is the total productivity of all carbon-containing products. For CO-free selectivity calculations, CO productivity was excluded from P tot. By reporting CO-free selectivity, we highlight the catalyst’s performance in converting CO2 into desired chemicals [23]. 2.4 In situ DRIFTS measurements In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was performed using a Nicolet IS50 spectrometer equipped with a mercury cadmium telluride detector. The setup included a Harrick Praying Mantis™ high-temperature reaction chamber designed for diffuse reflectance measurements. Prior to analysis, the catalyst was reduced in H2 atmosphere at 300 °C for 3 h. Then the reduced catalysts were placed in the reaction chamber. The reactor pressure was then increased to 3 MPa. For the hydrogenation studies, a CO2/H2 gas mixture (CO2:H2 = 1:1, total flow rate = 25 mL min−1) was introduced into the chamber. The temperature was subsequently increased from 180 °C to 230 °C and then 280 °C in steps. DRIFTS spectra were continuously collected during the reaction, with 128 scans averaged per spectrum at a resolution of 8 cm−1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure of the catalysts Both Mo-free CoAlPt (CAP) and Mo-modified CoAlPt (CAPM) catalysts were synthesized at pH values of 8.5 and 10, yielding four samples: CAP-8.5, CAP-10, CAPM-8.5, and CAPM-10. These catalysts were comprehensively characterized using a range of techniques. ICP-OES analysis (Table S1) showed that the Pt loading is 2.3–2.8 mol%, Co is 78.4–87.3 mol%, and Al is 9.6–12.9 mol%. In our previous work, we demonstrated that Pt promotes hydrogen spillover, improves catalyst reducibility, and increases the number of active sites [10]. Moreover, Pt induced spillover weakens H adsorption, thereby enhancing CO2 conversion and favoring CH4 formation. Besides, a low Al/Co ratio leads to an inverse catalyst structure upon reduction, in which alumina decorates Co nanoparticles to form a unique metal–oxide interface [9]. This architecture increases the density of active sites and optimizes H binding affinity, facilitating CO2 activation and methane formation. Finally, ICP-OES confirmed the incorporation of 5.6–5.9 mol % Mo via ion exchange, verifying the successful introduction of Mo into the CoAlPt matrix to further modulate the catalyst’s structure and performance. XRD patterns of the calcined catalysts ( Fig. 1a) display characteristic reflections corresponds to the (111), (022), (113), (222), (004), (115), and (044) planes of a spinel-type structure (ICSD-98–006–9367). Notably, no diffraction peaks corresponding to Mo or Pt species were observed in any sample (Fig. 1a), likely due to their low content and high dispersion or small particle size. XPS analysis of the calcined catalysts revealed distinct electronic states associated with Co and Mo species. The Co 2p3/2 spectra (Fig. 1b) exhibited peaks at 781.18–781.38 eV and 779.89–780.03 eV, corresponding to Co2+ and Co3+, respectively [24]. Deconvolution results (Table S2) indicated that Mo incorporation led to a shift in the Co 2p peaks toward higher binding energies, accompanied by a decrease in the Co2+/(Co2+ + Co3+) ratio in the CAPM samples. The Mo 3d spectra (Fig. S1) suggested the existence of Mo6+ (MoO3) and displayed well-defined peaks at 235.13–235.16 eV (Mo6+ 3d3/2) and 231.98–232.01 eV (Mo6+ 3d5/2), with binding energies slightly lower than that of unsupported MoO3 (232.5 eV for 3d5/2) [25,26]. This shift, combined with the increase in Co binding energies, suggests electron transfer from Co to Mo, indicative of interfacial electronic interactions between Mo and Co species [27]. The O 1 s spectra (Fig. 1c) exhibited two distinct components: lattice oxygen (Oα) at 530.05–530.20 eV and chemisorbed oxygen (Oβ) at the oxygen vacancy site at 531.03–531.12 eV [28–30]. Upon Mo incorporation, the fraction of Oβ increased (Table S3), indicating an elevated concentration of surface oxygen vacancies. This enhancement is likely due to the formation of small MoO3 particles containing abundant oxygen vacancies [31,32]. Additionally, Mo doping resulted in a shift of O 1 s binding energies toward higher values, further suggesting modifications in the local electronic environment of oxygen species. In short, the precipitated catalyst precursor primarily consists of Co and Al hydroxides with intercalated OH− ions. Upon mixing with MoO4 2− in solution, an anionic exchange occurs between OH− and MoO4 2−, resulting in the formation of MoO4 2−-intercalated Co and Al hydroxides [33]. Upon calcination at 400 °C, the intercalated MoO4 2− decomposes to form MoO3, as reported in the literature [34]. The small MoO3 particles possess abundant oxygen vacancies. These oxygen vacancies play a crucial role in modulating the adsorption behavior of H2 and CO2. H2-TPR was conducted to evaluate the reducibility of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 2a, the TPR profile of the reference MoPt/Al2O3 catalyst prepared via impregnation reveals the reduction behavior of Pt and Mo species over a temperature range of 100–700 °C. The initial reduction peak corresponds to the transformation of PtOx to metallic Pt [35], while the peak at approximately 450 °C is attributed to the reduction of Mo6+ to Mo4+, and a subsequent peak at 720 °C is assigned to the further reduction of Mo4+ to Mo2+ [36]. For the Co-based catalysts, two distinct reduction peaks (denoted as α and β) were observed. The low-temperature α peak (170–250 °C) corresponds to the stepwise reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and then to metallic Co0 and the reduction of Pt oxides and Pt-O-Co bonds [10,37]. The high-temperature β peak (250–400 °C) is associated with the reduction of Co2+ species that are strongly interacting with the oxide [37]. Upon Mo incorporation, the α peak shifted slightly to higher temperatures, while the β peak exhibited a more pronounced shift toward higher temperatures. This behavior suggests that Mo addition enhances metal oxide interaction between the Co species and the oxides [11]. The XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. 2b. Diffraction peaks at 41.4°, 44.2°, 47.2°, and 75.4° are ascribed to face-centered cubic (FCC) and hexagonal close-packed (HCP) metallic Co (PDF #96–901–1616) [38]. Upon Mo incorporation, a marked decrease in the signal-to-noise ratio of the Co0 diffraction peaks was observed. Further structural insights were provided by TEM analysis of the reduced catalysts (Fig. 2c). The reduced CAPM-10 sample displayed aggregated nanoparticles. High-resolution TEM imaging (Fig. 2d) revealed three characteristic lattice fringes with spacings of 1.98 Å, 2.01 Å, and 2.13 Å, which can be assigned to the (111) plane of FCC-Co0 [39], the (002) plane of HCP-Co0 [40], and the (411) plane of MoO3 [41], respectively. Elemental mapping via EDX (Fig. 2e–i) confirmed the homogeneous spatial distribution of Co, Al, Pt, and Mo throughout the sample. The activation of H2 on the catalyst surfaces was further probed by H2-TPD measurements. Fig. 3a shows that the H2-TPD profiles feature α-peaks between 150 and 250 °C—assigned to H2 desorption from Pt–Co ensemble sites—and β-peaks above 300 °C, which arise from H2 release at Co–Al or Co–Mo interfacial sites [42]. Upon Mo incorporation, both α- and β-peaks shifted toward lower temperatures. This is attributed to the hydrogen spillover phenomenon facilitated by the incorporation of MoO3, which promotes hydrogen desorption [43]. The total H2 uptake increased in the Mo-doped samples (Table S4, Fig. S2). This phenomenon is also attributed to the hydrogen spillover effect, wherein dissociated hydrogen atoms formed on metallic cobalt (Co0) and platinum (Pt0) migrate onto partially reduced MoO3 species. These reduced Mo sites can effectively stabilize the spilled-over hydrogen, thereby expanding the spatial distribution of hydrogen adsorption sites [44]. The surface basicity of catalysts plays a crucial role in CO2 hydrogenation reactions. To evaluate the surface basic properties of the CAPM catalysts, CO2-TPD measurements were carried out. As shown in Fig. 3b, three distinct desorption peaks—designated as α, β, and γ—were observed within the temperature range of 100–800 °C, corresponding to weak (150–350 °C), medium (350–500 °C), and strong (>500 °C) basic sites, respectively. The weak basic sites are related with metal-oxygen pairs within the catalyst matrix, while medium and strong basic sites are ascribed to coordinatively unsaturated O2− species, which exhibit pronounced Lewis basicity [45,46]. A summary of CO2 uptake and the distribution of surface basic sites is presented in Fig. S3 and Table S5. Incorporation of Mo markedly increases the overall density of basic sites, with a particularly pronounced rise in medium/strong-strength sites. This effect is attributed to Mo-induced generation of surface oxygen vacancies as well as the Mo-Co interaction, which promote the formation of bidentate carbonate species exhibiting stronger intermediate adsorption [47]. 3.2 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance of CAP and CAPM catalysts was evaluated in a batch autoclave reactor at 180 °C and an initial pressure of 4 MPa, using a CO2/H2 ratio of 1 for 1 h. As shown in Fig. 4a, Mo-doped catalysts exhibited significantly enhanced CO productivity compared to Mo-free CAP, indicating that Mo incorporation facilitates the reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) reaction and promotes CO formation [48]. Notably, CH4 production was substantially suppressed upon Mo addition. For instance, CH4 productivity decreased from 13977 μmol gcat −1 h−1 (CAP-8.5) to 591 μmol gcat −1 h−1 (CAPM-8.5), and from 14265 to 1898 μmol gcat −1 h−1 for CAPM-10. Meanwhile, methanol productivity remained largely unaffected by Mo incorporation, whereas the formation of higher alcohols showed a slight decline. Furthermore, catalysts synthesized at pH 10 exhibited higher overall productivity compared to those prepared at pH 8.5, as discussed later in Section 3.3. Overall, Mo incorporation slightly reduced alcohol productivity but significantly improved their selectivity. For example, CAPM-10 achieved methanol and higher alcohol productivities of 187 and 333 μmol gcat −1 h−1, with corresponding CO-free selectivity of 7.7 % and 13.8 %, whereas CAP-10 showed productivities of 192.1 and 415.6 μmol gcat −1 h−1, with CO-free selectivity of 1.3 % and 2.8 % (Fig. 4b). 3.3 Effects of precipitation pH and reduction temperature We further investigated the influence of precipitation pH and reduction temperature on the structure and catalytic performance. ICP-OES analysis revealed that the elemental composition of the catalysts remained consistent across the range of precipitation pH values (Table S6). XRD patterns confirmed that all calcined samples exhibited a spinel structure ( Fig. 5a). Notably, the crystallite size decreased as the precipitation pH increased from 8.5 to 10, but increased again when the pH was raised to 10.5 (Table S6). This trend suggests a transition from a nucleation-dominated regime—where higher [OH−] concentrations promote rapid and homogeneous nucleation while limiting crystal growth [49]—to a growth-dominated regime at very high pH, consistent with Ostwald ripening through dissolution–reprecipitation [50]. The effect of precipitation pH on catalyst reducibility was examined via H2-TPR analysis (Fig. 5b). All samples displayed two distinct reduction peaks, in agreement with previous results (Fig. 2a). As the precipitation pH increased from 8.5 to 10, the reduction peaks shifted to higher temperatures, indicating stronger metal–oxide interactions. However, further increasing the pH to 10.5 resulted in a shift of the reduction peaks to lower temperatures. This behavior correlates with the evolution of crystallite size, as smaller crystallites are typically associated with stronger interactions between Co-Al/Mo oxides [51]. H2-TPD profiles (Fig. 5c) of the CAPM catalysts synthesized at varying precipitation pH exhibit two distinct desorption features: a low-temperature peak (α) and a high-temperature peak (β), consistent with the observations in Fig. 3a. As the pH increases from 8.5 to 10, the hydrogen adsorption strength enhances, suggesting improved hydrogen activation at the optimal pH. However, a further increase to pH 10.5 results in reduced adsorption strength, likely due to stronger hydrogen binding on smaller Co particles [52]. Moreover, gradual decrease in H2 adsorption capacity with increasing pH was observed (Table S7, Fig. S4). Similarly, CO2-TPD profiles (Fig. 5d) reveal that CO2 uptake increases with pH from 8.5 to 10, but declines at pH 10.5 (Table S8, Fig. S5). Notably, the distribution of weak CO2 adsorption sites follows a similar volcano-like trend. This behavior is attributed to variations in Co crystallite size as a function of precipitation pH [53]. As smaller crystallites inherently expose a larger fraction of under-coordinated metal–oxygen linkages (i.e. M–O pairs at steps, edges and corners) relative to bulk lattice sites. The catalytic performance of CAPM catalysts synthesized at varying precipitation pH values was systematically evaluated at 180 °C and 4 MPa with CO2/H2 ratio of 1 for 1 h. As shown in Fig. 6a, CO productivity remained relatively stable across the pH gradients (8.5–10.5). In contrast, methane and alcohol productivity exhibited volcano-type trends, peaking at pH 10 (1988 μmol gcat −1 h−1 CH4, 521 μmol gcat −1 h−1 alcohol with 333 μmol gcat −1 h−1 C2+OH). Fig. 5e presents the H2-TPD profiles of CAPM-8.5 catalysts reduced at different temperatures (200–400 °C). With increasing reduction temperature, the H₂ uptake decreases while the desorption peaks shift to higher temperatures. This behavior is attributed to the development of strong metal–oxide interactions, which suppress the overall adsorption capacity while enhancing the adsorption strength of surface *H [54–56]. In addition, the fraction of weakly adsorbed hydrogen initially increases and then decreases with increasing reduction temperature (Table S9, Fig. S6). This trend is attributed to the competing effects of cobalt metallization—which promotes weak hydrogen adsorption [42] —and the progressive development of strong metal–oxide interactions, which enhance adsorption strength [56]. As the reduction temperature rises, the simultaneous increase in Co metallization and SMSI intensity gives rise to the observed nonmonotonic behavior. Fig. 5f presents the CO2-TPD profiles of the CAPM-8.5 catalyst reduced at various temperatures. As the reduction temperature increases, the overall CO2 adsorption capacity decreases, while the fraction of weak basic sites increases (Table S10, Fig. S7). The decline in CO2 uptake is attributed to the development of strong metal–oxide interactions [54–56], whereas the decrease in CoO amount due to increasing reduction temperature leads to increasing fraction of weakly adsorbed CO2 [57]. Fig. 6b illustrates the productivities of the CAPM-8.5 catalyst reduced at various temperatures (200–400 °C). Within this range, CO is the predominant product, and the reduction temperature shows minor influence on its productivity, ranging from 2313 μmol gcat −1 h−1 to 2688 μmol gcat −1 h−1. The productivities of methane and higher alcohols exhibit a volcano-shaped trend with increasing reduction temperature, with methane reaching a maximum of 675 μmol gcat −1 h−1 at 250 °C and higher alcohols peaking at 127 μmol gcat −1 h−1 at 300 °C. In contrast, methanol productivity remains relatively constant across the investigated reduction temperatures, ranging from 160 μmol gcat −1 h−1 to 205 μmol gcat −1 h−1. 3.4 Effects of reaction conditions The catalytic performance of CAPM-8.5 and CAPM-10 was systematically evaluated under varying reaction conditions, including temperature, reaction time, and gas composition. As shown in Fig. 7a and b, the productivities of methane and alcohols increased progressively with rising temperature from 160 °C to 200 °C, while CO productivity began to decline above 180 °C. The enhanced CO2 conversion at elevated temperatures can be attributed to improved reaction kinetics. However, at temperatures exceeding 180 °C, excessive hydrogen activation facilitates deep hydrogenation of reaction intermediates, thereby promoting hydrocarbon formation [58], meanwhile reducing the formation of CO at higher temperature. The influence of gas composition on the catalytic performance is shown in Fig. 7c and d. Under H2-deficient conditions (CO2/H2 = 3:1), hydrocarbon formation was significantly suppressed, and CO2 primarily underwent the reverse water–gas shift reaction to produce CO. Increasing the H2 partial pressure (CO2/H2 = 1:3) markedly enhanced the formation of CH4 and alcohols, consistent with the thermodynamic favorability of these hydrogenation pathways under H2-rich conditions [59]. Time-resolved studies (Fig. 7e and f) demonstrated a gradual decline in productivities with increasing reaction time, which is likely attributed to reactant depletion inherent to the batch reaction system. 3.5 Structure-performance correlation and reaction mechanism The incorporation of Mo into the CAP catalyst framework not only influence the catalyts' structure but also modulates the strength and distribution of surface adsorption sites, thereby influencing both catalytic activity and selectivity. As shown in Fig. 8a, the TOFs for CO2 conversion exhibits a positive correlation with the fraction of weakly adsorbed *H and *CO2 species. Weak adsorption facilitates rapid adsorption–desorption dynamics, minimizing site blockage by intermediates and enhancing the frequency of catalytic turnovers—resulting in a higher overall TOF [60,61]. Furthermore, weak *CO2 adsorption helps circumvent the thermodynamic sink associated with strongly adsorbed *CO2, thereby promoting its subsequent transformation to products [62], with methane as primary product [10]. In contrast, an increased fraction of strongly adsorbed *H and strongly/medium adsorbed *CO2 is associated with a higher CO/CH4 productivity ratio and methanol selectivity (Fig. 8b and c). Strong CO2 adsorption favors C–O bond cleavage, thereby promoting CO and methanol formation [63–65]. Moreover, strongly bound *H limits its availability for hydrogenation steps to methane, contributing to enhanced CO and methanol selectivity [66,67]. Moreover, higher alcohol synthesis is favored on catalysts that provide a moderate fraction of strongly adsorbed *H together with medium-to-strong *CO2 adsorption (Fig. 8d), indicating that C–C coupling occurs between methane-derived and CO/methanol-derived intermediates. Hence, maintaining an optimal balance between weakly and medium/strongly adsorbed *H/*CO2 is critical for directing selectivity toward higher alcohols. Notably, these correlations are based on the properties of the reduced catalysts. However, under hydrogenation conditions in a H2/CO2 atmosphere and aqueous environment, structural changes in the catalyst may occur, potentially leading to deviations from the established correlations. To gain deeper mechanistic insights into the formation of CH4, CO, methanol, and higher alcohols, in situ DRIFTS was employed to monitor surface intermediates during CO2 hydrogenation. The measurements were carried out over a temperature range of 180–280 °C under a H2/CO2 ratio of 1. The DRIFTS spectra for the CAP-10 ( Fig. 9a and c) and CAPM-10 (Fig. 9b and d) catalysts revealed characteristic bands corresponding to gas-phase CO2 (2260–2380 cm−1) [68] and adsorbed *CO2 species (3596, 3729, 3700 cm−1) [69–71]. With increasing temperature from 180 °C to 230 °C, bands associated with C1 intermediates appeared, including *CO (2077, 1750 cm−1) [72], HCO3 − (1437 cm−1), monodentate carbonate species *m-CO3 2− (1534 cm−1), bidentate carbonate species *b-CO3 2− (1363 cm−1), monodentate formate species *m-HCOO (1868, 1698 cm−1) [73–75], bidentate formate species *b-HCOO (1590 cm−1) [76,77], *CH3 (1342 cm−1) [78], and CH4 (3014, 1303 cm−1) [79]. Further heating to 280 °C led to the emergence of bands assignable to *CH3O (1457, 1056 cm−1) [80,81] and *CH3CH2O (1473, 1419 cm−1) [82,83] (Fig. 9a and b), indicative of C–C coupling and higher alcohol formation pathways. Comparative analysis revealed that the Mo-doped CAPM-10 catalyst exhibited significantly intensified *b-CO3 2− and *b-HCOO bands. Simultaneously, the intensity of CH4-related bands was notably diminished, confirming that Mo doping effectively suppresses methanation. The normalized data obtained at 180 °C (Fig. 9a and b) further demonstrate that the CAPM catalyst promotes the formation of *b-HCOO, which may be derived from *b-CO3 2− interacting stronger with the catalysts’ surface [84]. Accordingly, this favors the formation of *CHxO and *CO intermediates while inhibiting their conversion to CH4 [85–87]. Based on comprehensive experimental data analysis, we systematically elucidated the role of Mo species in modulating the performance of CoAlPt catalysts. Within the complex reaction network of CO2 hydrogenation, the primary reaction pathway begins with the adsorption of CO2 and H2 on the catalyst surface. Under reaction conditions, H2 dissociates into active *H species, which subsequently react with adsorbed *CO2 to form the *HCOO intermediate [88]. This intermediate undergoes *H-assisted reduction at surface active sites, generating key intermediates such as *CO *CHx and *CHxO [89–92]. *CO and *CHx further convert to CO and CH4 [89–92]. In parallel, *CHxO intermediates may be hydrogenated to methanol or undergo coupling with *CHx to form higher alcohols [89,93]. Based on the proposed reaction mechanism, further formation of propanol and butanol may proceed via *CHx-*CHx-*CHxO and *CHx-*CHx-*CHx-*CHxO coupling pathways. The selectivity toward various surface intermediates was quantitatively analyzed based on this carbon chain growth route (Note S1). As shown in Fig. 11a, the selectivity toward *CO exhibits an inverse correlation with that of *CHx, whereas a slight positive correlation is observed between the selectivity toward *CHxO and *CO (Fig. 11b). This observation can be attributed to the fact that *CHx primarily originates from *m-HCOO species, while *CO and CHxO are mainly derived from *b-HCOO species [85,86]. Additionally, the selectivity of *CHxO toward methanol is inversely correlated with its selectivity toward higher alcohols (Fig. 11d), supporting the notion that methanol and higher alcohols are generated through competitive reaction pathways. Furthermore, the selectivity of *CHx incorporated into higher alcohols increases proportionally with the total *CHx selectivity (Fig. 11e), aligning with the proposed mechanism in which carbon chain growth via *CHx-*CHx-*CHxO and *CHx-*CHx-*CHx-*CHxO coupling, with subsequent hydrogenation to propanol and butanol. Notably, Mo plays a crucial role in modulating the surface reactivity of Co-based catalysts. Its incorporation enhances the density of surface oxygen vacancies and promotes the formation of bidentate carbonate and formate species [94], which in turn facilitates CO and methanol production [85–87]. Although the formation of *CHx intermediates is suppressed, their concentration remains sufficient to sustain higher alcohol synthesis. Consequently, the overall yield of higher alcohols decreases only slightly, while the selectivity toward alcohols increases due to the suppression of competing reaction pathways. 4 Conclusion In this study, the strategic incorporation of molybdenum into CoAlPt catalysts (CAPM) via ion exchange has been demonstrated as an effective approach to modulate product selectivity in CO2 hydrogenation, significantly shifting the catalytic pathway away from methane and towards CO and alcohols. The optimized CAPM catalyst achieved a notable total alcohol productivity of 521 μmol gcat −1 h−1 with an alcohol selectivity of 21.5 % (CO-free), of which 64.0 % constituted higher alcohols (C2+OH). Concurrently, methane formation was drastically suppressed from 14265 to 1898 μmol gcat −1 h−1, while CO productivity increased by near three folds. Comprehensive characterization, including XRD, XPS, H2-TPR, H2/CO2-TPD, and in situ DRIFTS, revealed that molybdenum integrates into the Co catalysts structure. This incorporation facilitates electron transfer from Co to Mo, increases surface oxygen vacancies, and critically alters the adsorption properties of the catalyst. Specifically, Mo promotion led to an increased proportion of medium and strongly adsorbed *CO2 species, crucial for selectivity tailoring in CO2 hydrogenation. Mechanistic investigations indicate that these Mo-induced modifications steer the reaction pathway towards bidentate *HCOO intermediate conversion, diminishing the deep hydrogenation route to CH4 and favoring the formation of CO and alcohols. These findings underscore the significant potential of molybdenum as a promoter to tailor the active sites and surface chemistry of Co-based catalysts. The elucidated mechanistic insights into how Mo modulates adsorption strengths and reaction intermediates offer valuable guidance for the rational design of new catalysts with enhanced selectivity for CO2 conversion into value-added chemicals and fuels, particularly methanol and higher alcohols. To advance the practical application of this catalytic system, future work should aim to lower the Co and Pt loadings to reduce catalyst cost, while also investigating catalyst shaping strategies to ensure suitability for large-scale reactor operation. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 offers a sustainable route to convert a major greenhouse gas into value-added fuels and chemicals. Among various catalysts, cobalt (Co)-based materials have attracted attention due to their structural versatility and high activity; however, their strong hydrogenation capacity typically favors methane formation over higher-value products such as alcohols. In this study, we report a Mo-promoted CoAlPt catalyst synthesized via ion exchange to modulate product selectivity in CO2 hydrogenation. The Mo-promoted CoAlPt catalyst achieved a notable alcohol productivity of 521 μmol gcat −1 h−1 with an alcohol selectivity of 21.5 % (CO-free), of which higher alcohols accounted for 64.0 %. Simultaneously, methane formation was significantly suppressed (from 14,265 to 1898 μmol gcat −1 h−1), while CO productivity increased by nearly three folds. Mechanistic investigations attribute this performance enhancement to Mo-induced modulation of Co active sites, which promotes the formation of medium and strongly adsorbed *CO2 species. This shifts the reaction pathway toward bidentate *HCOO intermediate conversion, ultimately reducing CH4 formation and favoring alcohol production. These findings highlight the potential of Mo as a promoter in Co-based catalysts for tuning selectivity in CO2 hydrogenation.
